abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Inter-Governmental
            Authority on Development (IGAD) Regional Human Immune
            Deficiency Virus (HIV) and Acquired Immune Deficiency
            Syndrome (AIDS) Partnership Program (IRAPP) Support Project
            for Africa were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, risk to development outcome was significant,
            Bank performance was moderately unsatisfactory, and Grantee
            performance was moderately satisfactory. Some lessons
            learned included: complex regional projects require
            particular support and scrutiny to ensure quality at entry
            and subsequent implementation success. Measuring behavioral
            change outcomes related to cross-border and mobile
            populations (CBMPs) interventions is challenging and may not
            be advisable. Careful reporting of appropriate baselines,
            targets, and actual values, is critical to monitor project
            progress and determine project success. Implementation
            arrangements should be kept as simple as possible.
            Implementation agencies should be carefully selected to
            minimize problems. Service delivery institutions invested
            into should be accessible to the population being targeted.
            Future projects targeting CBMPs should consider targeting
            HIV and AIDS services at select hot spots and broaden
            support strategies beyond HIV and AIDS. The use of a
            standard agreement (contract) for Borrowers when contracting
            United Nation (UN) agencies under Bank financed projects is critical.
